Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: An Efficient Computational Approach for Wave and Surge Attenuation in Wetlands and Applications in Flood Risk Reduction
Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal develops an accurate and efficient method for modeling the interaction of fluid with numerous flexible plant stems (modeled as bendable cylinders) at a wide range of Reynolds numbers. Research activities include deriving new mathematics of kernel functions for bottom-clamped and bendable cylinders, verifying and validating model output, investigating the relation between the drag force and the bending angle and the link between the lateral clearance in a cylinder cluster and the effectiveness of wave and surge attenuation, and upscaling the model to infer macroscale parameters for large-scale simulations to test hypotheses of wetland resilience and flood risk reduction. Three educational programs: Summer Outreach, Minority Internship, and Graduate Student Exchange, provide opportunities for communities and minorities to participate in research and inter-university collaborations.

Continued climate change and sea level rise pose a major threat to coastal habitats and communities worldwide. The impact of sea level rise has caused increased coastal erosion and flooding. For example, owing to subsidence, sea level rise and human interventions, the Mississippi River Delta and the Louisiana coast lose one acre of wetland every 24 minutes, which accounts for 80% of the total annual loss of coastal wetlands in the continental United States. The chronic wetland loss in south Louisiana has considerably weakened the natural defense against catastrophic floods, such as Hurricanes Katrina and Rita (2005). Over 1,500 people lost their lives and several major coastal populations were crippled for months after the hurricanes passed. Mitigating flood damage and reducing the threat of storm surges are imperative. It has been recognized that vegetation in wetlands can effectively reduce the flow speed. Results from the proposed research will not only provide insight to wave and surge attenuation in coastal wet-lands for coastal engineers and managers, but also serve as useful references for mechanical, civil, environmental, and ocean engineering concerning interactions of fluid with structures and plant canopies. The developed simulation tools will benefit society in better protecting the coastal ecosystem from impacts of storms and sea level rise and reducing the risk of flooding. Knowledge gained from the research will be assimilated in multi-channel education to train two graduate students, to involve minorities in mathematical science, and to stimulate the interest of communities in computational mathematics. This project will educate the public about the gravity of coastal flooding and erosion in Louisiana.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Vegetation stems naturally grown in wetlands near coastal regions have demonstrated effects of absorbing wave and surge energy and preventing land erosion. Large arrays of vegetation stems along coastal wetlands could serve as a natural protection against coastal erosion. The major goals of this research are to establish the knowledge about how vegetation stems work as the wave energy attenuator, what optimal configurations could be for mitigating wave energy, and how to hydrodynamically quantify forces and torques of individual stem and arrays of stems from incoming water waves. To this end, vegetation stems are simulated as immersed cylinders on which drag forces and torques from water waves are computed at varied configurations and conditions. These data provide references for further studies of reducing coastal land erosion and mitigating coastal damage. 

In terms of the achieved intellectual merit, this project has advanced the knowledge and ability of modeling arrays of vegetation stems. Modeling arrays of immersed stems in water is challenging, especially for large numbers of them. The principal investigator - Dr. Liu developed accurate and economical kernel functions in Virtua Cylinders Model (VCM) for finite numbers of vegetation stems as well as hundreds and thousands of them. Dr. Liu conducted systematic studies using Direct Numerical Simulation (DNS) on fine boundary-resolved mesh to obtain reliable data for comparisons. VCM results have been compared with DNS data to verify the accuracy and to demonstrate the economy in terms of computational time and memory requirement. Good improvement has been achieved. The most time-consuming computations for resolving the surface of each cylinder due to wall effect (non-slip boundary condition) are relieved, only much less work - resolving volumes inside and around cylinders is needed through volume integrals implemented with highly accurate numerical quadrature. Specially tailored kernel functions in the model have facilitated the accuracy and efficiency in the computation. VCM is one to two orders faster than DNS in computational intensity. The developed spectral element code has been tested and optimized on a single Linux computer as well as multi-core parallel computers. The VCM model serves as a good complement to other existing models. 

The broader impacts in advancing the discovery and understanding of wave/surge attenuation with vegetation stems have achieved. The VCM model could simulate many vegetation stems of varied configurations with much less computational overhead than other existing plant-resolving models (only a fraction of DNS at a comparable resolution). Complex geometry and shape of vegetation could be handled with high accuracy owing to using the spectral element method. The most computational intensive parts of the algorithm have been identified, profiled, and optimized. Volume integral evaluations have been improved and verified. Hence, the overall computational efficiency, accuracy and scalability have improved noticeably.

The broader impacts in benefiting society has been achieved. The outcome of this project has positive contributions towards coastal and deltaic resilience. The VCM model is capable of predicting, especially in a sample wetland, wave and surge energy loss after sweeping through arrays of vegetation stems. Effective resistance of wave currents and wave energy reduction from a single, a few, and hundreds of vegetation stems have been established via parametrical and systematical simulation runs. Databanks and experience have been accumulated for further development of next generation computational model to investigate arrays of vegetation stems in even large scales and more complexity.
